text.p: The following are some of the leading stories in Finnish papers this morning.
- It may take a year for U.S. food and drug administration to approve food group Raisio's Benecol product offically as cholesterol- cutting agent, FDA official says.
- Wood and Allied Workers union representative says main focus in pay talks will be to improve employment -- says he believes in a broad pay deal despite paper workers' abstention.
- Next state budget is three billion markka below earlier estimates.
- Finance Ministry budget plans to combine lowest rates of value added tax, six and 12 percent, cut tax on medicines, books and movies, but raise tax on public transport.
- Crime, especially assaults, continuing to grow, statistics show.
- Finnish researchers found effective treatment for adult diabetes.
- Centralisation of food retailers has put heavy pressure on farm product prices: farmers should unite to resist, says Central Union of Agricultural Producers and Forest Owners (MTK).
- British oil service station chain Station 1 starts competing in Finland: market is worn out by competition already, Finnish sector representative says.
- Parliament speaker Riitta Uosukainen apologizes "for existing" in row over presidential powers.
- Finnish weather prophet, frog-owning professor Taisto Heikkila, plans to retire with his frogs: says ageing frogs start getting delirious and you cannot really rely on their weather forecasts.
- Finland has more more Internet users than any other country, and growth has amounted annually to 100 percent.
- European Commission has agreed to discuss Finland's special farming conditions -- problems from unfavourable climate for agriculture and high producer costs -- next autumn.
- Finland will announce its official stand on EU enlargement next autumn, says EU Minister Ole Norrback.
